questions.text: A 59-year-old man was previously diagnosed with pernicious anaemia. He was non-compliant with medication for several years. He now has unsteadiness and difficulty walking. Lesion in which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with gait unsteadiness in the background of untreated pernicious anaemia, strongly suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • SACD classically affects the dorsal columns (posterior columns) and lateral corticospinal tracts.
  • Involvement of the dorsal columns leads to loss of proprioception and vibration sense, causing sensory ataxia and a positive Romberg sign.
  • Corticospinal tract involvement leads to spastic weakness, extensor plantar, and sometimes hyperreflexia.
  • There may also be associated peripheral neuropathy, leading to loss of reflexes despite UMN signs.

Related Important Points:

  • Pernicious anaemia leads to vitamin B12 deficiency due to antibodies against intrinsic factor.
  • MRI spine may show hyperintense T2 lesions in the posterior and lateral columns.
  • Treatment includes parenteral vitamin B12, initially daily, then monthly for life in pernicious anaemia.

Explanation of other options:

Corpus callosum (Option A): Involved in disconnection syndromes (e.g., alien hand), not seen in B12 deficiency.

Spinothalamic tract (Option B): Carries pain and temperature; typically spared in SACD.

Thalamus (Option D): Responsible for sensory relay; its lesion causes hemisensory loss, not ataxia or SACD features.

questions.text: A 37-year-old lady has developed progressive weakness in the hands and feet over a week. There is some associated numbness and tingling in the hands and feet. She complains of breathing difficulty. She had several episodes of diarrhoea two weeks ago. On examination, there is slurring of speech. Her reflexes are all absent, and there is sensory loss in a glove and stocking pattern. Which is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acute lower motor neuron (LMN) quadriparesis preceded by a diarrheal illness, consistent with Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS), likely post-Campylobacter jejuni
  • She now has breathlessness, raising concern for impending respiratory failure.
  • The most urgent priority is to assess her respiratory function.
  • Vital Capacity (VC) measurement is critical:
    • FVC < 20 mL/kg → ICU admission recommended
    • FVC < 15 mL/kg → Intubation often necessary
  • Diaphragmatic weakness occurs in ~30% of GBS patients, often alongside bulbar muscle involvement.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS): (Post-infectious polyradiculoneuropathy) -

  • Immune-mediated demyelinationof the peripheral nervous system is often triggered by an infection such as viral (CMV), viral pneumonia or bacterial (classically Campylobacter jejuni).
  • CSF findings - Elevated proteinwith no pleocytosis - (albuminocytologic dissociation). Glucose is normal.
  • Pathogenesis: Cross-reaction of antibodies with gangliosides in the peripheral nervous system. Anti-GM1 antibodiesare positive in 25% of cases.

Clinical features:

  • The characteristic features of GBS are progressive symmetric ascending weakness. Itbegins in the legs and progressively ascends to involve the trunk, upper limbs and finally the bulbar muscles.
  • However, it tends to affect proximal muscles earlierthan the distal ones.
  • Sensory symptoms tend to be mild (e.g., distal paraesthesia, peripheral sensory neuropathy) with very few sensory signs(NO sensory loss).
  • Usually, there is a painlessprogression over days or weeks.
  • Areflexia - All tendon reflexes are absent, and the plantar responses were flexor.
  • Cranial nerve involvement, e.g. bilateral facial palsy
  • Autonomic dysfunction: e.g., urinary retention and postural hypotension & tachycardia.

Management:

  • IVIG(IV immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.
  • Regular monitoring of FVC(Forced vital capacity) to assess respiratory function.

Explanation of other options:

MRI (Option A): Not the first-line investigation in suspected GBS.

Lumbar puncture (Option B): Useful for diagnosis (CSF protein elevation), but not the immediate priority in a dyspneic patient.

EMG (Option D): Confirms diagnosis but is not helpful in acute respiratory monitoring.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has been admitted to the hospital for investigation of progressive weakness in her legs. For the past 5 years. The patient's mother has similar difficulties with weakness and sensory problems. Examination revealed a power of 3/5 distally in the upper and lower limbs with a glove and stocking pattern sensory loss to pain and touch. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The chronic progressive weakness, sensory loss, and positive family history suggest a genetic neuropathy, specifically Hereditary Sensory Motor Neuropathy (HSMN), also known as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT).
  • Most common subtype: CMT1 (demyelinating form).
  • Typical features:
    • Distal weakness in both upper and lower limbs
    • Glove-and-stocking sensory loss
    • Pes cavus, hammer toes, distal wasting (especially peroneal muscles)
    • Progressive course, often starting in childhood or early adulthood
  • Nerve conduction studies show uniformly slowed NCVs and hypertrophic nerves with onion bulb formations on biopsy.

Related Important Points:

  • Inheritance is usually autosomal dominant.
  • Motor symptoms usually predominate over sensory symptoms.
  • Disease progresses slowly over the years with high penetrance in affected families.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing and nerve conduction studies.
  • Friedreich's ataxia: Autosomal recessive, presents with ataxia, dysarthria, and cardiomyopathy, not glove-stocking neuropathy. (Option B)
  • Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy: Acquired immune-mediated; lacks family history and tends to have more rapid progression. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has developed weakness over the past 3 weeks, which has affected his walking. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, he had decreased sensation peripherally in the legs and also flaccid reflexes in the ankles. A CT of the head was normal, and a lumbar puncture was done.Results were:Protein 0.75(<0.43 g/l)Glucose 4 (3.3 to 4.4 mmol/l)Lymphocytes 7 (< 5/mm3) What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The dissociation between a high CSF protein, normal glucose and a lack of CSF cellular responsein a person with an acute or subacute polyneuropathy is diagnostic of Guillain-Barre syndrome.
  • In GBS, CSF protein is elevated in most patients after the second or third week of illness.
  • The gamma globulin fraction is usually raised. Cells, usually monocytes, are found in 20% of cases.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS): (Post-infectious polyradiculoneuropathy):

  • Immune-mediated demyelinationof the peripheral nervous system is often triggered by an infection, such as viral (CMV), viral pneumonia or bacterial (classically Campylobacter jejuni).

Pathogenesis: Anti-GM1 antibodies are positive in 25% of cases.

Clinical features:

  • The characteristic features of GBS are progressive symmetric ascending weakness.
  • No sensory loss
  • Areflexia - All tendon reflexes are absent, and the plantar responses were flexor.
  • Cranial nerve involvement, e.g., diplopia
  • Autonomicdysfunction: e.g., urinary retention and postural hypotension & tachycardia.
  • Diaphragmaticweakness occurs in 30% of patients.

Management:

  • IVIG(IV immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.
  • Regular monitoring of FVC(Forced vital capacity) to assess respiratory function.
  • Poliomyelitisis a disease that occurs during childhood and can cause some disability. The history of vaccines may not be taught there. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tuberculous meningitis presents with an acute history of fever, headache, altered sensorium, convulsions, etc. The history of TB foci may be there elsewhere in the body. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 22-year-old man injured himself whilst snowboarding. On examination, he has weakness of elbow flexion and loss of sensation over the radial aspect of her forearm. Which of the Following nerves is damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elbow flexion weakness and sensory loss over the lateral forearm are classic signs of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • The fibres of the musculocutaneous nerveoriginate in the lower cervical spinal cord (usually C5 to C7) and travel via the lateral cord of the brachial plexus.

Innervation:

  • Sensorysupply - Lateral forearm via the lateral cutaneous nerve.
  • Motorsupply - To the biceps brachii, which helps in elbow flexion.
  • Injury typically leads to:
    • Weakness of elbow flexion
    • Preserved triceps reflex
    • Loss of cutaneous sensation on the lateral forearm

Explanation of other options:

Brachioradialis nerve (Option B): No such standalone nerve; brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve.

Radial nerve (Option C): Supplies wrist and finger extensors; does not innervate biceps or lateral forearm skin.

Median nerve (Option D): Supplies forearm flexors and hand muscles; not responsible for elbow flexion or lateral forearm sensation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of weakness in the arms and legs, accompanied by tingling. He had several episodes of bloody diarrheal illness two weeks ago. On examination, there was leg and arm weakness and flaccid deep tendon reflexes. Which test would best help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nerve conduction studies (NCS) are the best diagnostic test to confirm Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) and its subtypes.
  • This patient presents with classical features of post-infectious GBS:
    • Acute flaccid weakness
    • Sensory symptoms (tingling)
    • Areflexia
    • Recent bloody diarrhoea, likely due to Campylobacter jejuni
  • NCS findings depend on GBS subtype:
    • AIDP (demyelinating): Prolonged distal latencies, slowed conduction, conduction block
    • AMAN/AMSAN (axonal): Reduced CMAP amplitudes without latency prolongation
  • CSF (not listed here) would show albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein, normal cells).
  • Anti-GM1 antibodies may be positive in axonal variants.

Explanation of other options:

Electroencephalography (Option B): Used in seizure disorders; not relevant for peripheral neuropathy.

MRI (Option C): May be used to rule out cord lesions, but is not diagnostic in GBS.

Anti-ACh antibody (Option D): Seen in myasthenia gravis, not GBS.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presents with a 5-day history of ascending muscle weakness in both hands and feet. EMGs confirm acute demyelinating sensory and motor neuropathy. What treatment should be started?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) is a first-line treatment for Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), proven to hasten recovery and reduce complications.
  • The clinical scenario and EMG findings point to acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP), the most common form of GBS.
  • Characteristic features of GBS:
    • Progressive, symmetric, ascending weakness
    • Hyporeflexia or areflexia
    • Often preceded by respiratory or gastrointestinal infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni)
    • May involve autonomic dysfunction
  • Treatment options:
    • IVIG at 2 g/kg over 5 days
    • Plasmapheresis is equally effective
    • No added benefit from combining the two treatments
  • Steroids are not effective and may worsen the course.

Explanation of other options:

Corticosteroids (Option A): Ineffective in GBS; not recommended for treatment.

Tacrolimus (Option B): Immunosuppressant used in organ transplantation; no role in GBS.

Amitriptyline (Option C): May help in neuropathic pain but not in treating the underlying disease.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male presents with a six-month history of a gradually increasing burning sensation in his feet. Examination revealed normal cranial nerves and higher mental function. He has normal bulk, tone, power, light touch and pinprick sensation, coordination and reflexes in upper and lower limbs. With which of the following are these clinical findings consistent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A pure burning-type pain in the presence of a normal neurological exam is characteristic of small fibre sensory neuropathy.
  • Small fibres (Aδ and C fibres) are responsible for pain and temperature
  • These fibres are unmyelinated or thinly myelinated, and damage to them results in:
    • Burning, tingling, or electric-shock-like sensations
    • Normal reflexes, proprioception, and light touch, which are mediated by large fibres
  • Common causes:
    • Diabetes mellitus (especially early neuropathy)
    • Amyloidosis, HIV, Sjögren's syndrome
  • Diagnosis often requires specialised testing (e.g., skin biopsy, quantitative sensory testing) as nerve conduction studies are typically normal

Explanation of other options:

Diabetic amyotrophy (Option A): Proximal asymmetric motor neuropathy with weakness and wasting not seen here.

Large fibre sensory neuropathy (Option B): Causes glove and stocking loss of vibration/proprioception and absent reflexes not consistent with normal exam.

Motor neuron disease (Option C): Presents with motor signs, including wasting, fasciculations, or spasticity, not pure sensory symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is found to have absent ankle jerks and gait disturbance. Which of the following investigations is not indicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ferritin is not related to neuropathy or gait disturbance and is thus not indicated in this context.
  • Absent ankle jerks and gait disturbance suggest a neuropathy or dorsal column dysfunction, seen in:
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency → sensory ataxia, pyramidal signs, peripheral neuropathy
    • SLE → can cause demyelinating neuropathy; ANA testing is appropriate
    • Cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis → inherited lipid storage disorder; associated with peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, cataracts, xanthomas
  • Vitamin B12 level: to rule out subacute combined degeneration
  • ANA titre: to evaluate for autoimmune causes like SLE
  • Cholestanol level: diagnostic for cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis
  • Ferritin: a marker of iron stores; relevant in anaemia but not related to neuropathy or gait dysfunction

Explanation of other options:

ANA titre (Option A): Elevated in SLE, which can cause peripheral neuropathy.

Vitamin B12 levels (Option B): Essential to rule out SACD, which causes neuropathy and sensory ataxia.

Cholestanol levels (Option C): Diagnostic for cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis, which presents with ataxia and neuropathy.

choices.text: Bulbar involvement occurs in about 50% of cases

questions.text: Which of the following clinical manifestations suggests Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bulbar involvement, manifesting as dysphagia, dysarthria, and facial weakness, occurs in nearly 50% of GBS cases and indicates a risk of aspiration and respiratory failure.
  • GBS is an acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy typically following infection (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni).
  • Bulbar muscle involvement reflects cranial nerve involvement, especially CN VII, IX, and X.
  • Other typical features include:
    • Symmetrical ascending motor weakness
    • Areflexia or hyporeflexia
    • Elevated CSF protein with normal glucose and minimal cells (albuminocytologic dissociation)
    • Autonomic dysfunction, such as tachycardia, BP fluctuations, and urinary retention

Explanation of other options:

Asymmetrical involvement (Option A): GBS typically causes symmetric weakness; asymmetry is rare (~9%).

Brisk tendon reflexes (Option B): GBS causes areflexia, not hyperreflexia.

Normal CSF protein (Option D): CSF protein is typically elevated after the first week of onset.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female is admitted with progressive weakness following a trivial flu-like illness. Which of the following would exclude Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) as the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A defined sensory level suggests spinal cord pathology and is not a feature of Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • GBS is an acute, post-infectious, immune-mediated polyradiculoneuropathy affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • Typical features include:
    • Symmetrical ascending motor weakness
    • Areflexia or hyporeflexia
    • Mild distal sensory symptoms, but no discrete sensory level
  • A sensory level implies involvement of the spinal cord, as seen in transverse myelitis or compressive myelopathies, not GBS.
  • CSF findings show elevated protein with normal cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation). (Option B ruled out)
  • Autonomic dysfunction and cranial nerve involvement, including ophthalmoplegia (in Miller Fisher variant), are well-recognised features of GBS. (Option A ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • GBS is often triggered by Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, or other infections.
  • Monitoring of FVC is essential to detect respiratory compromise.
  • Treatment includes IVIG or plasmapheresis; steroids are not beneficial.
  • Miller Fisher variant presents with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia.

Explanation of other options:

Ophthalmoplegia (Option C): Seen in the Miller Fisher variant of GBS.

choices.text: Haematological abnormalities may not be seen in approximately 40% of patients with subacute combined degeneration due to cobalamine deficiency
In patients with food cobalamine malabsorption, oral cobalamine is sufficient to correct the deficiency
Treatment of cobalamine deficiency will completely reverse the neurological manifestations
Methylmalonic acid and Homocysteine levels may be elevated in Cobalamin deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neurological deficits due to cobalamine deficiency may not completely reverse, especially if treatment is delayed.
  • Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) affects the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Up to 40% of patients with SACD may lack hematologic findings such as macrocytic anaemia or hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • Neurological symptoms, especially if longstanding, are only partially reversible in about 50% of cases, even with B12 therapy.
  • Methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels are sensitive indicators of early B12 deficiency.
  • Oral cobalamine is effective in food-cobalamin malabsorption, where intrinsic factor and terminal ileum function are intact.

Related Important Points:

  • In pernicious anaemia, parenteral B12 is necessary due to an intrinsic factor deficiency.
  • SACD presents with sensory ataxia, spasticity, and proprioception loss.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with parenteral or high-dose oral cobalamine is key to preventing irreversible damage.

Explanation of other options:

Haematological abnormalities may not be seen in approximately 40% of patients with SACD (Option A): Many patients with neurologic B12 deficiency lack macrocytic anaemia or other blood findings.

In patients with food cobalamine malabsorption, oral cobalamine is sufficient (Option B): These patients can absorb free cobalamin; oral therapy with high doses (e.g., 1000â€¯mcg/day) is effective.

Methylmalonic acid and Homocysteine levels may be elevated (Option D): These are early, sensitive markers of tissue-level B12 deficiency and precede hematologic or neurologic signs.

choices.text: Cobalamine deficiency may be a cause of the above findings
Dietary deficiency of copper may also lead to similar clinical features
Haematological abnormalities, if present, point to the diagnosis of Vitamin B12 deficiency
Excess Zinc is a known factor that reduces copper absorption

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with unsteadiness of gait of one year duration. On examination, he has sensory loss in the stocking and glove pattern, with absent ankle jerk and pyramidal signs and sensory ataxia. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Haematological abnormalities may occur not only in Vitamin B12 deficiency but also in copper and Vitamin E deficiency; hence, they are not exclusive to B12 deficiency.
  • Neurological findings like sensory ataxia, distal areflexia, and pyramidal signs are typical of subacute combined degeneration (SACD), seen in B12 deficiency, but can also be mimicked by copper and Vitamin E deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to macrocytic anaemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and pancytopenia.
  • Copper deficiency leads to microcytic anaemia, neutropenia, and sometimes pancytopenia. (Option A ruled out)
  • Vitamin E deficiency can show acanthocytosis on peripheral smear.
  • Excess zinc induces metallothionein production in the intestine, which preferentially binds copper, leading to its malabsorption. (Option D ruled out)

Related Important Points:

  • Sensory ataxia with pyramidal signs suggests posterior column and corticospinal tract involvement (SACD).
  • Copper and Vitamin E deficiencies are close mimickers of B12 deficiency neurologically.
  • Clinical clue: Presence of anaemia does not conclusively point to B12 deficiency; it must be interpreted along with red cell indices and smear.

Explanation of other options:

Cobalamine deficiency (Option A): Can cause all listed neurological features, including SACD.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with features of polyneuropathy and ataxia. Which of the following diseases is least likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tangier's disease is the least likely cause of combined polyneuropathy and ataxia among the given options.
  • It typically causes asymmetric multiple mononeuropathies or symmetric polyneuropathy, but ataxia is not a prominent feature.
  • Conditions like Friedreich's ataxia, abetalipoproteinemia, vitamin E deficiency, and Refsum's disease all present with both polyneuropathy and ataxia.
  • Tangier's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene, leading to extremely low HDL levels and high triglycerides.
  • It typically presents with yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, neuropathy, and lymphadenopathy, but not significant cerebellar signs or sensory ataxia.

Related Important Points:

  • Friedreich's Ataxia (Option C): Involves spinocerebellar tracts, pyramidal tracts, and peripheral nerves; associated with cardiomyopathy and pes cavus.
  • Abetalipoproteinemia (Option B) presents with steatorrhea, retinitis pigmentosa, acanthocytosis, and polyneuropathy.
  • Vitamin E deficiency (Option D): Causes pigmentary retinopathy, night blindness, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Refsum's disease: Characterised by retinitis pigmentosa, cerebellar ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated CSF protein.
  • Tangier's disease: Although a neuropathy is seen, ataxia is not a prominent feature; it tends to show mononeuropathies and lipid abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is evaluated for early-onset stroke. He also gives a history of burning pain in both feet since his late teenage years. What clinical sign is most likely to be seen on examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Angiokeratomas are a hallmark cutaneous finding in Fabry disease, which presents with early-onset stroke and peripheral neuropathic pain.
  • Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A.
  • Neuropathy presents as burning pain in the hands and feet (acroparesthesia) from adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Characteristic angiokeratomas are dark red to black papular lesions, often seen between the umbilicus and knees, especially in the bathing trunk distribution.
  • Other systemic findings: hypohidrosis, renal impairment, cardiomyopathy, cerebrovascular disease, corneal verticillata, and lenticular opacities.

Related Important Points:

  • Fabry disease is a key differential for young stroke patients with neuropathy.
  • Stroke results from small-vessel vasculopathy affecting the brain, heart, and kidneys.
  • It is important to distinguish familial lipid disorders, which also cause early stroke but lack neuropathy or angiokeratomas.

Explanation of other options:

Tendon xanthomas (Option A): Seen in familial hypercholesterolemia, not

associated with neuropathic pain or angiokeratomas.

Palmar xanthomas (Option B): Suggestive of type III hyperlipoproteinemia, unrelated to Fabry disease.

Central obesity (Option C): Common in metabolic syndrome but not a feature of Fabry disease.

choices.text: Microcytic hypochromic anaemia with Basophilic stippling of RBC on peripheral smear

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes to the ER with an altered sensorium of insidious onset. Upon detailed history, his wife said that he had difficulty extending the wrist over the past 3 weeks without any sensory symptoms. You suspect heavy metal poisoning. What additional findings will you see?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of pure motor neuropathy (wrist drop) and altered mental status is highly suggestive of lead poisoning.
  • Lead toxicity affects the central and peripheral nervous system, presenting with encephalopathy and motor neuropathy (commonly wrist or foot drop).
  • It interferes with heme synthesis, causing microcytic hypochromic anaemia with basophilic stippling of red blood cells.
  • Associated findings include elevated serum coproporphyrin, bluish gum line, and abdominal colic in some cases.

Related Important Points:

  • Lead poisoning is one of the few heavy metal toxicities to cause pure motor neuropathy without sensory symptoms.
  • Encephalopathy is seen in both lead and mercury
  • Lead should be suspected in occupational exposure (battery, paint, plumbing) or in cases of progressive CNS symptoms with anaemia.

Explanation of other options:

Mee's lines (Option A): Seen in arsenic and thallium poisoning; presents as transverse white lines on nails, but not associated with motor neuropathy.

Acneiform lesions (Option B): Seen in thallium toxicity; usually accompanied by sensorimotor neuropathy, alopecia, and GI symptoms.

Patchy skin pigmentation (Option D): Also a feature of arsenic poisoning, often with painful sensorimotor neuropathy, not pure motor.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with diplopia. On examination, she has external ophthalmoplegia with absent pupillary reflexes, ataxia and areflexia. There is no limb weakness. Which of the following antibodies will be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia without limb weakness is characteristic of Miller Fisher Syndrome (MFS), a variant of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.
  • MFS is associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies in up to 90% of cases.
  • Pupillary involvement (absent reflexes) is seen due to parasympathetic nerve involvement.
  • Unlike typical GBS, limb weakness is usually absent or minimal.
  • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by the presence of anti-GQ1b and albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF.

Related Important Points:

  • MFS is considered part of the GBS spectrum and often follows viral infections.
  • Anti-GQ1b antibodies are also found in Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis, which may share overlapping features.
  • Treatment is usually with IVIG or plasmapheresis, similar to other GBS variants.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-GM1 antibody (Option A): Commonly seen in AIDP and AMAN types of GBS, typically with limb weakness.

Anti-GalNAc antibody (Option C): Also associated with AMAN variant, not specific for MFS.

Anti-GD1 antibody (Option D): Seen in motor axonal variants of GBS and rarely in MFS.
